DIV1.P: THE NABOB; A COMEDY. WRITTEN by Mr. FOOTE, PUBLISHED by Mr. COLMAN.
THE NABOB; A COMEDY, IN THREE ACTS. AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL in the HAYMARKET. WRITTEN BY THE LATE SAMUEL FOOTE, Esq. AND NOW PUBLISHED BY Mr. COLMAN.
LONDON, Printed by T. Sherlock, For T. CADELL, in the Strand. MDCCLXXVIII.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE, Spoken by Mr. FOOTE, At the Theatre-Royal in DUBLIN, On the 19th of November, 1773.
DIV1.L: UPWARDS of twenty years are sled and wasted
Since in this spot your favour first I tasted.
Urg'd by your smiles thro' various realms to roam,
The Muse now brings her motley cargo home;
For frugal Nature, with an equal hand,
Bestows peculiar gifts to every land.
To France she gave her rapid repartee,
Bows, and bons mots, fibs, fashions, flattery,
Shrugs, grins, grimace, and sportive gaiety:
Arm'd with the whole artillery of love,
Latium's soft sons possess the powers to move:
Humour, the foremost of the festive crew,
Source of the comic scene, she gave to you;
Humour, with arched brow, and leering eye,
Shrewd, solemn, sneering, subtle, slow and sly;
Serious herself, yet laughter still provoking,
By teasing, tickling, jeering, gibing, joking:
Impartial gift, that owns nor rank nor birth!
'Tis theirs who rule the realm, or till the earth;
Theirs who in senates wage the wordy war,
And theirs whose humble lot conducts the car:
If aught deriv'd from her adorns my strain,
You gave, at least discover'd first, the vein.
Should wide experience, or maturing age,
Have brought or mirth or moral to the stage,
To you, the patrons of the wilder song,
The chaster notes in justice must belong:
But should infirmities with time conspire,
My force to weaken or abate my fire,
Less entertainment may arise to you,
But to myself less danger will ensue.
If age contracts my muscles, shrills my tone,
No man will claim those foibles as his own;
Nor, if I halt or hobble thro' the scene,
Malice point out what citizen I mean:
No foe I fear more than a legal fury,
Unless I gain this circle for my jury.

STAGE.HI: Enter Lady Oldham and Sir John Oldham.

SP.P: NOT a syllable more will I hear!
Nay, but, my dear—
I am amazed, Sir John, at your meanness! or that you could submit to give his paltry proposals so much as a reading!
Nay, my dear, what would you have had me done?
Done? returned them with the con∣tempt they deserved. But, come, unfold! I am calm: Reveal the pretty project your precious head has produced.
Nay, my dear, as to that, my head produced—

Nay, I don't wonder that shame has tied up your tongue! But, come; I will spare the confusion, and tell you what you would say. Here, Lady Oldham, Sir Matthew Mite has just sent me a letter, modestly desiring that, in return for the ruin he has brought on me and my house, I would be so kind as to bestow upon him my darling daughter, the hopes of my— And is it possible you can be mean enough to think of such an alliance? Will you, Sir John, oblige me with an answer to a few short questions?
Without doubt.
I suppose you consider yourself as sprung from a family at least as ancient as any in the county you live in?
That I fancy will not be denied.
Nor was it, I fancy, dishonoured by an alliance with mine?
My Lady, the very reverse.
You succeeded, Sir, to a patrimony, which though the liberal and hospitable spirit of your predecessors would not suffer to encrease, yet their prudence took care should never be diminished?
True.

From the public and private virtues of
your ancestors, the inhabitants of the neighbour∣ing borough thought their best and dearest in∣terests in no hands so secure as in theirs?
Right.

Nor till lately were they so tainted by the fashion of the times, as to adopt the egregious absurdity, That to be faithfully served and pro∣tected above, it was necessary to be largely bribed and corrupted below?
Why, I can't say, except now and then a bit of venison, or an annual dinner, they have ever put me to any great——

Indulge me yet a moment, Sir John! In this happy situation, did the last year chear∣fully close; our condition, though not opulent, affluent, and you happy in the quiet possession of your family honours.
There is no gainsaying of that.
Now, look at the dismal, shocking reverse!
There is but too much reason in what your ladyship says.
And consider, at the same time, to whom you are obliged.
Why, what could we do? your ladyship knows there was nobody more against my giving up than yourself.

Let me proceed. At this crisis,
preceded by all the pomp of Asia, Sir Matthew Mite, from the Indies, came thundering amongst us; and, profusely scattering the spoils of ruined provinces, corrupted the virtue and alienated the affections of all the old friends to the family.
That is nothing but truth.

Compelled by the same means to defend those that were employed in attacking your interest, you have been obliged deeply to encumber your fortune; his superior address has procured a return, and probably your petition will complete the ruin his opposition began.
Let us hope all for the best.
And who can tell, but you may be soon forced to part with your patrimony, to the very insolent worthless individual, who has been the author of your distress?
I would sooner perish, my Lady!
Parallel instances may be produced; nor is it at all unlikely, but Sir Matthew, taking a liking to your family mansion, has pursued this very method to compel you to sell it.
It is, my dear, to avoid this necessity that I wish you to give his letter a reading.
Is it possible, not to mention the mean∣ness, that you can be weak enough to expect any real service from that infamous quarter?
Who can tell, my love, but a con∣sciousness of the mischief he has done us, may have roused some feelings that—
His feelings! will he listen to a pri∣vate complaint, who has been deaf to the cries of a people? or drop a tear for particular dis∣tress, who owes his rise to the ruin of thousands?
Well, Lady Oldham, I find all that I say signifies nothing. —But here comes brother Thomas; two heads are better than one; let us take his opinion, my love.

What need of any opinion? the case is too clear; nor indeed, if there had been a necessity for consulting another, should I have thought your brother the properest man to ad∣vise with on the occasion.
And why not? there is not a mer∣chant whose judgment would be sooner taken.

Perhaps not, on the value of mer∣chandize, or the goodness of a Bill of Exchange: But there is a nicety, a delicacy, an elevation of sentiment, in this case, which people who have narrowed their notions with commerce, and con∣sidered during the course of their lives their in∣terest alone, will scarce comprehend.
So, sister! what! upon your old topic, I find?
Sir!
Some pretty comparisons, I suppose, not much to the honour of trade.
Nay, brother, you know I have always allowed merchants to be a useful body of men; and considered commerce, in this country, as a pretty resource enough for the younger shoots of a family.
Exceedingly condescending, indeed! And yet, sister, I could produce you some in∣stances where the younger shoots have flou∣rished and throve, when the reverend trunk has decayed.
Perhaps, brother Thomas—
Nay, nay, don't let us revive our antient disputes!—You seem warm; no misun∣derstanding, I hope?
No, no; none, in the least: You know, my lady's temper's apt to be lively now and then.
Nay, sister—But, come! what ha occasioned this mighty debate?
You know, brother, how affair stand between Sir Matthew and us.
Well!
He has sent us here a kind of compromise; I don't know well what to ca it; a sort of a treaty.
That in your hand?
Yes; and I can't prevail on my lady to give it a reading.
And why not?
To what end?
A very natural one; in order to know the contents.
Of what importance can they be to us?
That the letter will tell you. But surely, Lady Oldham, you are rather too nice. Give it me!
Is it your ladyship's pleasure?

Psha! here's a rout, indeed!—One would be apt to suspect that the packet was pestilential, and came from the Archipelago, instead of the Indies. Now let us see what this formidable memorial contains! opens the letter. “To Sir John Oldham. Sir Matthew Mite hav∣ing lately seen, at Lady Levant's rout, the eldest Miss Oldham, and being struck with her personal charms, proposes to her father ”the following treaty.
A very monarchical address!

P.Q: “Imprimis; Upon a matrimonial union between the young lady and him, all hostilities and contention shall cease, and Sir ”John be suffered to take his seat in security.

SP.P: That he will do, without an obliga∣tion to him.
Are you, sister, certain of that?
You don't harbour the least doubt of our merits?
But do they always prevail?

There is now, brother Thomas, no danger to dread; the restraint the popular part of government has in this instance laid on itself, at the same time that it does honour to them, distributes equal justice to all.

And are you aware what the expence will be to obtain it?—But, pray, let me pro∣ceed!—“Secondly, as Sir Matthew is bent upon a large territorial acquisition in England, and Sir John Oldham's finances are at present a lit∣tle out of repair, Sir Matthew Mite will make up the money already advanced in another name, by way of future mortgage upon his estate, for the entire purchase, five lacks of ”roupees.
Now, Sir John! was I right in my guess?
Your ladyship is never out.—But, brother Thomas, these same lacks—to what may they amount?
Sixty thousand, at least.
No inconsiderable offer, my lady.
Contemptible! But pray, Sir, proceed.

P.Q: “Or if it should be more agreeable to the parties, Sir Matthew will settle upon Sir John and his Lady, for their joint lives, ”a jagghire.

SP.P: A jagghire?
The term is Indian, and means an annual income.
What strange jargon he deals in!
His stile is a little Oriental, I must own; but most exceedingly clear.
Yes, to Cossim Ali-Khan, or Mier Jaffeir. I hope you are near the conclusion.

But two articles more, reads “And that the principals may have no cares for the younger parts of their family, Sir Matthew will, at his own expence, transport the two young ladies, Miss Oldham's two sisters, to Madrass or Calcutta, and there procure them ”suitable husbands.
Madrass, or Calcutta!
Your patience, dear sister!—“And as for the three boys, they shall be either made supercargoes, ships' husbands, or go out cadets ”and writers in the Company's service.
Why, he treats my children like a parcel of convicts: Is this their method of sup∣plying their settlements?

This, with now and then a little kid∣napping, dear sister.—Well, madam, you have now the means of getting rid of all your offspring at once: Did not I tell you the paper was worth your perusal? You will reply to his wish; you can have no doubts, I suppose.
Not the least, as I will shew you. Tears the letter. And, if Sir John has the least spirit or pride, he will treat the insolent principal as I do his proposals.

But that method, as things stand, may not be altogether so safe. I am sorry you were so hasty in destroying the letter: If I remember rightly, there is mention made of advancing money in another man's name.
We have been compelled to borrow, I own; but I had no conception that he was the lender.
That's done by a common contrivance; not a country lawyer but knows the doctrine of transfer.—How much was the sum?
Ten thousand pounds.
And what, Sir John, were the terms?
As I could give no real security, my estate being settled till my son John comes of age▪ I found myself obliged to comply with all that was asked.
A judgment, no doubt.
They divided the sum, and I gave them a couple.
Which will affect not only your per∣son, but personal property; so they are both in his power.
Too true, I am afraid!
And you may be sent to a gaol, and your family turned into the streets, whenever he pleases.
How! Heaven forbid!

Not the least doubt can be made.— This is an artful project: No wonder that so much contrivance and cunning has been an over∣match for a plain English gentleman, or an inno∣cent Indian. And what is now to be done? Does your daughter Sophy know of this letter?
Sir John?
It reached my hands not ten minutes ago.
I had some reason to think, that, had you complied, you would not have found her very eager to second your wishes.
I don't know that, brother: Young girls are easily caught with titles and splendor; magnificence has a kind of magick for them.

I have a better opinion of Sophy. You know, Lady Oldham, I have often hinted, that my boy was fond of his cousin; and possibly
my niece not totally averse to his wish; but you have always stopp'd me short, under a notion that the children were too nearly allied.
Why, brother, don't yon think——

But that, sister, was not the right reason; you could have easily digested the cousins, but the compting-house stuck in his way: Your favourite maxim has been, that citizens are a distinct race, a sort of creatures that should mix with each other.
Bless me, brother, you can't conceive that I—
Nay, no apology, good Lady Oldham! perhaps you have a higher alliance in view; and let us now consider what is to be done. You are totally averse to this treaty?
Can that be a question?
Some little management is necessary, as to the mode of rejection: As matters now stand, it would not be prudent to exasperate Sir Matthew.
Let Sir John discharge the debt due to him at once.
But where shall we get materials?
Can that be a difficult task?

Exceedingly so, as I apprehend: But few can be found to advance so large a sum on such slender security; nor is it to be expected,
indeed, unless from a friend to relieve, or a foe to ruin.
Is it possible Sir Matthew can have acted from so infernal a motive, to have advanced the money with a view of distressing us deeper?
Sir Matthew is a profound politi∣cian, and will not stick at trifles to carry his point.
With the wealth of the East, we have too imported the worst of its vices. What a horrid crew!
Hold, sister! don't gratify your re∣sentment at the expence of your justice; a gene∣ral conclusion from a single instance is but in∣different logick.
Why, is not this Sir Matthew——

Perhaps as bad a subject as your passion can paint him: But there are men from the Indies, and many too, with whom I have the honour to live, who dispense nobly and with hospitality here, what they have acquired with honour and credit elsewhere; and, at the same time they have increased the dominions and wealth, have added virtues too to their country.
Perhaps so: But what is to be done? Suppose I was to wait on Sir Matthew myself.
If your ladyship is secure of com∣manding your temper.
Mercy on us, brother Thomas, there's no such thing as trusting to that!
You are always very obliging, Sir John! if the embassy was to be executed by you——
Come, come, to end the dispute, I will undertake the commission myself.
You will take care, brother, to make no concessions that will derogate from——
Your dignity, in my hands, will have nothing to fear.—But should not I see my niece first? she ought to be consulted, I think.
By all means.
For, if she approves of the knight, I don't see any thing in the alliance so much to be dreaded.
I will send Sophy to her uncle di∣rectly; but I desire the girl may be left to her∣self; no undue influence!Exit.
The caution was needless.

Why, really, now, brother, but that my lady's too warm, I don't see any thing so very unreasonable in this same paper here that lies scattered about. But, I forget, did he men∣tion any thing of any fortune he was to have with the girl?
Pho! a paltry consideration, below his concern.
My lady herself must own there is something generous in that.
Will you stay and represent the case to Sophy yourself?

SP.L: Your uncle, child, has something to say to you:
You know he loves you, my dear, and will ad∣vise you for the best.Exit.

SP.P: Come hither, Sophy, my love! don't be alarmed. I suppose my lady has opened to you, that Sir Matthew has sent a strange kind of a romantic letter.
But she did not seem, Sir, to suppose that it deserved much attention.

As matters now stand, perhaps more than she thinks. But come, my good girl, he explicit: Suppose the affairs of your family should demand a compliance with this whimsical letter, should you have any reluctance to the union proposed?
Me, Sir? I never saw the gentleman but once in my life.
And I don't think that would interest you much in his favour.
Sir!
No prepossession? no prior object that has attracted your notice?
I hope, Sir, my behaviour has not occasioned this question.
Oh, no, my dear; it naturally took its rise from the subject. Has your cousin lately been here?
Sir!
Tom Oldham, my son?
We generally see him, Sir, every day.
I am glad to hear that: I was afraid some improper attachment had drawn him from the city so often of late.
Improper! I dare say, Sir, you will have nothing of that kind to fear from my cousin.
I hope not: And yet I have had my suspicions, I own; but not unlikely you can re∣move 'em: Children rarely make confidants of their fathers.
Sir!
Similarity of sentiments, nearness of blood, and the same season of life, perhaps may have induced him to unbosom to you.
Do you suppose, Sir, that he would discover to me, what he chose to conceal from so affectionate a father?

Nay, prithee, Sophy, don't be grave! What, do you imagine I should think his pre∣ferring
your ear to mine, for a melting passionate tale, any violent breach of his duty?
You are merry, Sir.
And who knows but you might re∣pay the communication with a similar story? You blush, Sophy.
You are really pleased to be so very particular, that I scarce know what answer to make.

Come, my good niece, I will perplex you no longer: My son has concealed nothing from me; and did the completion of your wishes depend on my approbation alone, you would have but little to fear: But my lady's notions are so very peculiar, you know, and all her prin∣ciples so determined and fixed——
The merits of my cousin, which she herself is not slow to acknowledge, and time, might, I should hope, soften my mother.

Why then, my dear niece, leave it to time, in most cases the ablest physician. But let your partiality for Tom be a secret!—I must now endeavour to learn when I can obtain an audience from Sir Matthew.
An audience from him?

Yes, child; these new gentlemen, who from the caprice of Fortune, and a strange
chain of events, have acquired immoderate wealth, and rose to uncontroled power abroad, find it difficult to descend from their dignity, and ad∣mit of any equal at home. Adieu, my dear niece! But keep up your spirits! I think I fore∣see an event that will produce some change in our favour.Exeunt.
I own the place of a porter, if one can bear the confinement—And then, Sir Matthew has the character of—low tap. Use no cere∣mony, Mr. Janus; mind your door, I beseech you.
No hurry! keep your seat, Mr. Con∣serve; it's only the tap of a tradesman: I make those people stay till they collect in a body, and so let in eight or ten at a time; it saves trouble.
And how do they brook it?

Oh, wonderfully well, here with us. In my last place, indeed, I thought myself bound to be civil; for as all the poor devils could get was good words, it would have been hard to have been sparing of them.
Very considerate!
But here we are rich; and as the fel∣lows don't wait for their money, it is but fair they should wait for admittance.
Or they would be apt to forget their condition.
True.
Upon the whole, then, you do not re∣gret leaving my lord?
No; Lord Levee's place had its sweets, I confess; perquisites pretty enough: But what could I do? they wanted to give me a rider.
A rider?
Yes; to quarter Monsieur Frissart, my Lady's valet de chambre, upon me; so you know I could not but in honour resign.
No; there was no bearing to be rid by a Frenchman; there was no staying in after that.
It would have been quoted as a pre∣cedent against the whole corps.
Yes. Pox on 'em! our masters are damned fond of encroachments. Is your pre∣sent duty severe?
I drudge pretty much at the door; but that, you know, is mere bodily labour: But then, my mind is at ease; not obliged to rack my brain for invention.
No?
No; not near the lying here, as in my last place.
I suppose not, as your master is but newly in town; but you must expect that branch to encrease.
When it does, I shall insist the door be done by a deputy.Two raps.
Hark! to your post!
No; sit still! that is some aukward body out of the city; one of our people from Leadenhall-Street; perhaps a director; I sha'n't stir for him.
Not for a director? I thought he was the commanding officer, the Great Captain's captain.
No, no; quite the reverse; the tables are turned, Mr. Conserve: In acknowledgment for appointing us their servants abroad, we are so obliging as to make them directors at home.
That rap will rouse you, I think.
Let me take a peep at the wicket. Oh, oh! is it you, with a pox to you? How the deuce came your long legs to find the way hi∣ther?—I shall be in no haste to open for you.
Who is it?

That eternal teizer, Sir Timothy Tall∣boy.
When once he gets footing, there is no such thing as keeping him out.
What, you know him then?
Yes, rot him, I know him too well! he had like to have lost me the best place I ever had in my life.
How so?

Lord Lofty had given orders on no account to admit him. The first time, he got by me under a pretence of stroking Keeper the house-dog; the next, he nick'd me by desiring only just leave to scratch the poll of the parrot, Poll, Poll, Poll! I thought the devil was in him if he deceived me a third; but he did, notwith∣standing.
Prithee, Janus, how?

By begging to set his watch by Tompion' clock in the Hall; I smoaked his design, and laid hold of him here: taking hold of his coat. As sure as you are alive, he made but one leap from the stairs to the study, and left the skirt of his coat in my hand?
You got rid of him then?

He made one attempt more; and, for fear he should slip by me, (for you know he is as thin as a slice of beef at Marybone-Gardens), I slapped the door in his face, and told him, the dog was mad, the parrot dead, and the clock
stood; and, thank Heaven, I have never sat eyes on him since.Knock louder.
But the door!
Time enough.—You had no particular commands, master Conserve?
Only to let you know that Betsy Robins has a rout and supper on Sunday next.
Constant still, Mr. Conserve, I see. I am afraid I can't come to cards; but shall be sure to attend the repast. A nick-nack, I suppose?

Yes, yes; we all contribute, as usual: The substantials from Alderman Sirloin's; Lord Frippery's cook finds fricasees and ragouts; Sir Robert Bumper's butler is to send in the wine; and I shall supply the desert.
There are a brace of birds and a hare, that I cribbed this morning out of a basket of game.
They will be welcome.—Knock louder. But the folks grow impatient!
They must stay till I come.—At the old place, I suppose?
No; I had like to have forgot! Betsy grew sick of St. Paul's, so I have taken her a house amongst the new buildings; both the air and the company is better.
Right.

To say truth, the situation was disagree∣able on many accounts. Do you know, though I took care few people should behave better at Christmas, that because he thought her a citizen, the housekeeper of Drury-Lane Theatre, when his master mounted, refused her a side-box?
No wonder Miss Betsy was bent upon moving.—What is the name of her street?
Rebel-Row: It was built by a messenger who made his market in the year forty-five. But shall Miss Robins send you a card?

No, no; I shall easily find out the place. Knock. Now let us see; who have we here? Gads my life, Mrs. Match'em! my master's amorous agent: It is as much as my place is worth to let her wait for a minute.

STAGE.HI: Enter Mrs. Match'em, some Tradespeople, who bow low to Janus, and Thomas Oldham.

SP.P: So, Sir! this is pretty treatment, for a woman like me to dangle at your gate, sur∣rounded by a parcel of tradespeople!
I beg pardon; but, madam—
Suppose any of my ladies had chanced to drive by: In a pretty situation they'd have seen me! I promise you I shall make my com∣plaints to Sir Matthew.
I was receiving some particular com∣mands from my master.
I shall know that from him. Where is he? let him know I must see him directly; my hands are so full I have not a moment to spare.
At that door the groom of the cham∣ber will take you in charge; I am sure you'll be admitted as soon as announced.
There is as much difficulty to get a sight of this signior, as of a member when the parliament's dissolved!Exit.
Soh! what, you have brought in your bills? damned punctual, no doubt! The stew∣ard's room is below.—And, do you hear? when you are paid, be sure to sneak away without see∣ing me.
We hope you have a better opi∣nion—
Well, well, march! Exe. Tradesmen. So, friend; what is your business, pray?
I have a message to deliver to Sir Matthew.
You have? and pray what is the pur∣port?
That's for his ear alone.
You will find yourself mistaken in that.
How?
It must make its way to his, by passing thro' mine.
Is that the rule of the house?
Ay; and the best way to avoid idle and impertinent pratlers.
And of that you are to judge?
Or I should not be fit for my post. But, you are very importunate; who are you? I suppose a Jew broker, come to bring my master the price of the stocks?
No.
Or some country cousin, perhaps?
Nor that neither.
Or a voter from our borough below? we never admit them but against an election.

Still wide of the mark.—Aside. There is but one way of managing here; I must give the Cerberus a sop, I perceive.—Sir, I have really business with Sir Matthew, of the utmost importance; and if you can obtain me an in∣terview, I shall think myself extremely obliged.
As I see, Sir, by your manner, that it is a matter of moment, we will try what can be done; but you must wait for his levee; there is no seeing him yet.
No?

He is too busy at present; the waiter
at Almack's has just brought him home his macaroni dress for the hazard-table, and is in∣structing him to throw the dice with a grace.
Then where can I wait?
If you will step into that room, I will take care to call you in time.Exit Mr. Old. —Looking at the money. A good sensible fellow! At first sight, how easily one may be mistaken in men!Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II. A Chamber. Sir Matthew Mite in his gaming dress, a Waiter attending.

SP.P: MAIN and chance?
Five to nine, please your honour.
I am at all that is set. How must I proceed?
With a tap, as the chances are equal; then raise the box genteelly and gently, with the finger and thumb.
Thus?
Exactly, your honour. Cinque and quater: You're out.
What is next to be done?
Flitt the bones with an air of indiffe∣rence, and pay the money that's set.
Will that do?
With a little more experience, your honour.
Then pass the box to my neighbour?
Yes; or you make a back hand, if you please.
Cou'dn't you give me some general rules? for then, you know, I might practise in private.
By all means. Seven, Sir, is better nicked by a stamp.
So?
Yes. When you want to throw six and four, or two cinques, you must take the long gallery, and whirl the dice to the end of the table.
Thus?
Pretty well, please your honour. When your chance is low, as tray, ace, or two deuces, the best method is to dribble out the bones from the box.
Will that do?
Your honour comes rapidly on.
So that, perhaps, in a couple of months, I shall be able to tap, flirt, stamp, dribble, and whirl, with any man in the club?
As your honour has a genius, you will make a wonderful progress, no doubt: But these nice matters are not got in a moment; there must be parts, as well as practice, your honour.
What! parts for the performance of this?

This? Why, there's Sir Christopher Clumsey, in the whole losing his fortune, (and
I believe he was near a twelvemonth about it) never once threw, paid, or received, with one atom of grace.
He must have been a dull devil, indeed.
A mere dunce! got no credit by losing his money; was ruined without the least reputation.
Perhaps so. Well, but, Dick, as to the oaths and phrases that are most in use at the club?
I have brought them here in this pa∣per: As soon as your honour has got them by heart, I will teach you when and in what man∣ner to use them.
after looking at the paper.How long do you apprehend before I may be fit to appear at the table?
In a month or six weeks. I would advise your honour to begin in the Newmarket week, when the few people left do little better than piddle.
Right: So I shall gain confidence against the club's coming to town.
Mrs. Crocus, from Brompton, your honour.
Has she brought me a bouquet?
Your honour?
Any nosegays, you blockhead?
She has a boy with a basket.
Shew her in! Exit Servant.—Well, Dick, you will go down to my steward, and teach him the best method of making a rouleau. And, do you hear? let him give you one for your pains.
Your honour's obedient! You'd have me attend every morning?
Without doubt: It would be madness to lose a minute, you know.Exit Waiter.
Well, Mrs. Crocus; let us see what you have brought me. Your last bouquet was as big as a broom, with a tulip strutting up like a ma∣gistrate's mace; and, besides, made me look like a devil.

That at present is more than I'll own.— I fancy, Mr. A—a—a, you have made some mistake.
Some mistake?
I don't recollect that I ever had the ho∣nour to know you.
What, don't you remember Phil Putty?
No.
That was prentice to Master Gibson, the glazier in Shoreditch?
No.
That at the Blue-Coat-Hospital has often saved your bacon by owning your pranks?
No.

No! What, then, mayhap you ben't Mat Mite, son of old John and Margery Mite, at the Sow and Sausage in St. Mary Axe, that took the tarts from the man in Pye-corner, and
was sent beyond sea, for fear worse should come on it?
You see, Mr. Putty, the glazier, if that is your name and profession, you are entirely out in this matter; so you need not repeat your vi∣sits to me.Exit.

Now here's a pretty purse-proud son of a——who, forsooth, because he is grown great by robbing the heathens, won't own an old friend and acquaintance, and one too of the livery beside! Dammee, the great Turk himself need not be ashamed to shake hands with a citi∣zen! "Mr. Putty the glazier!" well, what a pox am I the better for you? I'll be sworn our company has made more money by a single election at Brentford, than by all his exploits put together.Exit.

STAGE.HI: Enter Mr. Thomas Oldham, followed by a Servant.

SP.P: Sir Matthew Mite is not come?
No, Sir.
Is Tom here?
Mr. Oldham is, I believe, with Miss in the parlour.

Let him know I would see him. Exit Serv. Poor boy! Nay, I sincerely grieve for them both! this disappointment, like an
untimely frost, will hang heavy on their tender years: To conquer the first and finest feelings of nature is an arduous task!
So, Tom! still attached to this spot, I perceive?
Sir, I arrived but the instant before you.
Nay, child, I don't blame you. You are no stranger to the almost-invincible bars that oppose your views on my niece; it would be therefore prudent, instead of indulging, to wean yourself by degrees.
Are there no hopes, then, Sir, of subduing my aunt?
I see none: Nay, perhaps, as mat∣ters now stand, a compliance may be out of her power.
How is that possible, Sir? out of her power?
I won't anticipate: Misfortunes come too soon of themselves; a short time will explain what I mean.
You alarm me! Would you conde∣scend to instruct me, I hope, Sir, I shall have discretion enough——

It would answer no end. I would have you both prepare for the worst: See your
cousin again; and remember, this perhaps, may be the last time of your meeting.
The last of our—
But Sophy is here. I must go in to Sir John.Oldham bows low to Sophy and retires
Sir! What can be the meaning of this▪ My uncle Oldham avoids me! you seem shocked! no additional misfortune, I hope?
My father has threatened me, in obscure terms, I confess, with the worst that can happen.
How!
The total, nay, perhaps, immediate loss of my Sophy.
From what cause?
That in tenderness he chose to con∣ceal.
But why make it a mystery? have you no guess?

Not the most distant conception. My lady's dislike would hardly prompt her to such violent measures. I can't comprehend how this can possibly be; but yet my father has too firm, too manly a mind, to encourage or harbour vain fears.
Here they come. I suppose the riddle will soon be explained.

STAGE.HI: Enter Sir John, Lady, and Thomas Oldham.

SP.P: But what motive could he have for demanding this whimsical interview? he could not doubt your credentials, or think his pre∣sence could be grateful to us.
I have delivered my message.

Perhaps he depends on his rhetorical powers: I hear he has a good opinion of them. Stay, Sophy! Sir Matthew Mite, distrusting the message we begged your uncle to carry, de∣sires to have it confirmed by ourselves: I fancy, child, you will do yourself no violence in re∣jecting this lover. He is an amiable swain, I confess!
I shall be always happy in obeying your ladyship's orders.
Are you sure of that, Sophy? a time may soon come for the trial.
Well, in the main, I am glad of this meeting; it will not only put a final end to this business, but give us an opportunity of discussing other matters, my dear.
Is that your opinion, Sir John? I fancy he will not be very fond of prolonging his visit.
Sir Matthew Mite!
Shew him in!—Now, Sir John, be on your guard; support this scene with a dignity that becomes one of your birth and—
Never fear my dignity, love. I warrant you I'll give him as good as he brings.

I find the whole tribe is convened.—I hope I am not an intruder; but I confess the extraordinary answer I received from the mouth of this worthy citizen, to a message conveyed by my secretary, induced me to question its au∣thenticity, unless confirmed by yourselves.
And why should you think our reply so very extraordinary?
You must give me leave to smile at that question.
A very decisive answer, I own!
You are, Lady Oldham, a woman of the world, and supposed not to be wanting in sense.
Which this conduct of mine inclines you to doubt?
Why, to be plain, my condition and your own situation considered, prudence might have dictated a different reply.
And yet, Sir Matthew, upon the ma∣turest deliberation, all the parties, you see, persist in giving no other.
Is it so? You will permit me, Lady Oldham, to desire one of those reasons which influenced this august assembly upon the occasion?
They will, I dare say, appear but trifling to you.
Let us have them, however.
First, we think it right to have a little regard to her happiness, as she is indebted for her existence to us.
Which you think she risques in a union with me? Lady Oldham bows. And why so? I have the means to procure her, madam, those enjoyments with which your sex is chiefly delighted.

You will, Sir Matthew, pardon my weakness; but I would much rather see my child with a competence, nay, even reduced to an in∣digent state, than voluptuously rioting in plea∣sures that derive their source from the ruin of others.
Ruin! what, you, I find, adopt the po∣pular prejudice, and conclude that every man that is rich is a villain?

I only echo the voice of the public. Besides, I would wish my daughter a more solid establishment: The possessions arising from plun∣der very rarely are permanent; we every day see what has been treacherously and rapaciously gained, as profusely and full as rapidly squandered.
I am sorry, madam, to see one of your fashion, concur in the common cry of the times; but such is the gratitude of this country to those who have given it dominion and wealth.

I could wish even that fact was well founded, Sir Matthew. Your riches (which per∣haps too are only ideal) by introducing a general spirit of dissipation, have extinguished labour and industry, the slow, but sure source of national wealth.

To these refinements I have no time to reply. By one of your ladyship's hints I shall profit at least: I shall be a little more careful of the plunder I have made. Sir John Oldham, you recollect a small sum borrowed by you?
I do.
The obligations for which are in my possession at present.
I understand as much by your letter.
As I find there is an end of our treaty, it would be right, I think, to discharge them directly.
I can't say that is quite so convenient; besides, I understood the party was to wait till the time that Jack comes of age.

I am told the law does not understand what is not clearly expressed. Besides, the probable event of your death, or the young gentleman's
shyness to fulfil the agreement, are enough to put a man on his guard.
Now comes on the storm.
And, that my prudence might not suffer in that lady's opinion, I have taken some pre∣cautions which my attorney will more clearly unfold.—Mr. Rapine!
You will explain this affair to Sir John: I am a military man, and quite a stranger to your legal manoeuvres.
By command of my client, Sir Matthew, I have issued here a couple of writs.
Sir John!
What?
By one of which, plaintiff possesses the person, by t'other goods and chattels, of Sir John the defendant.
A definition very clear and concise!
Goods, Sir? what, must I be turned out of my house?
No, madam; you may stay here till we fell, which perhaps mayn't happen these two days. We must, indeed, leave a few of our people, just to take care that there is nothing embezzled.

A short respite, indeed! For a little
time, I dare say, my brother Oldham will afford us protection. Come, Sir John, nor let us in∣dulge that monster's malice with a longer sight of our misery.
You, madam, are a wife, and may go where you please; but as to Sir John—
Well!
He must not stir: We are answerable for the possession of him.
Of him? a prisoner? then indeed is our ruin complete!
Oh, uncle!—You have been pleased, Sir, to express an affection for me: Is it possible, Sir, you can be so cruel, so unkind to my parents—
They are unkind to themselves.
Let me plead for mercy! suspend but a little!—My uncle, you, Sir, are wealthy too!— Indeed we are honest! you will not run the least risque.
There is a condition, Miss, in which you have a right to command.
Sir!
It is in your power, and that of your pa∣rents, to establish one common interest amongst us.
Never! after rejecting, with the con∣tempt they deserved, the first arrogant offers you made, do you suppose this fresh insult will gain us?
I am answered.—I presume, Mr. Rapine, there is no longer occasion for me?

Stop, Sir! Mr. Oldham teaches me what I should do. Can I see their distress? Heaven knows with what eagerness I would sacri∣fice my own peace, my own happiness, to procure them relief!Kneels to Sir Matthew.

Rise, niece! nor hope to soften that breast, already made too callous by crimes! I have long seen, Sir, what your malice intended, and pre∣pared myself to baffle its purpose. I am instructed, Sir, in the amount of this man's demands on my brother: You will there find a sum more than sufficient to pay it.—And now, my dear sister, I hope you will please to allow a citizen may be useful sometimes.
Mr. Rapine, is this manoeuvre according to law?
The law, Sir Matthew, always sleeps when satisfaction is made.

Does it? Our practice is different in the Mayor's Court at Calcutta.—I shall now make my bow; and leave this family, whom I wished to make happy in spite of themselves, soon to regret the fatal loss sustained by their obstinate folly.

Nor can it be long, before the wisdom of their choice will appear; as by partaking of
the spoil, they might have been involved in that vengeance, which soon or late can't fail to fall on the head of the author: And, Sir, notwithstanding your seeming security, perhaps the hour of re∣tribution is near!

You must, Master Oldham, give me leave to laugh at your prophetic effusion. This is not Sparta, nor are these the chaste times of the Roman republic: Now-a-days, riches possess at least one magical power, that, being rightly dispensed, they closely conceal the source from whence they proceeded: That wisdom, I hope never to want.— I am the obsequious servant of this respectable family! Adieu!—Come along, Rapine!
Brother, what words can I use, or how can we thank you as we ought? Sir John! Sophy!

I am doubly paid, Lady Oldham, in supplying the wants of my friends, and defeating the designs of a villain: As to the mere money, we citizens indeed are odd kind of folks, and always expect good security for what we advance.
Sir John's person, his fortune, every——
Nay, nay, nay, upon this occasion we will not be troubled with land; If you, sister, will place as a pledge my fair cousin in the hands of my son—
I freely resign her disposal to you.
And I.

Then be happy, my children! And as to my young cousins within, I hope we shall be able to settle them without Sir Matthew's assistance: For, however praiseworthy the spirit of adventure may be, whoever keeps his post, and does his duty at home, will be found to ren∣der his country best service at last!Exeunt.
